name.text: 8.2.3.1 Example 3x3 linear system inverse matrix method

questiontext.text:
Solving three equations in three unknowns

It is much more tedious to use the inverse matrix to solve a system of three equations although in principle, the method is the same as for two equations.

Example

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} x_1 &- & 2x_2 & + & x_3 & = & 3\\ 2x_1 & + & x_2 & - & x_3 & = & 5\\ 3x_1 & - & x_2 & + & 2x_3 & = & 12 \\ \end{matrix}\]

and its matrix form \(AX = B\). One can find that \(|A|=10\) (check it!). Hence \(A^{-1}\) exists.

Solve it using the inverse matrix method.

Solution

  1. Find \(A^{-1}\) by the method of determinants.

    2. Form the matrix where each element of \(A\) is replaced by its minor:

    \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&-1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&1\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{cc}1&1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ 1&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 2&1\end{array}\right|\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}1&7&-5\\ -3&-1&5\\ 1&-3&5\end{array}\right].\)

    Now use the \(3\times 3\) array of signs to obtain the matrix of cofactors:

    The array of signs is \[\left[\begin{matrix} +&-&+\\ -&+&-\\ +&-&+ \\ \end{matrix}\right]\] so that we obtain \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&-7&-5\\ 3&-1&-5\\ 1&3&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\]

  2. Transpose this matrix and divide by \(|A|\) to obtain \(A^{-1}\).

    3. Transposing gives \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1\\ -7&-1&3\\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\] Finally, \[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{10} \left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1 \\ -7&-1&3 \\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\]

  3. Now use \(X=A^{-1} B\) to solve the system of linear equations.

    4. \[X=\frac{1}{10}\left[\begin{matrix}1&3&1\\ -7&-1&3\\ -5&-5&5\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} 3\\ 5\\ 12\end{matrix}\right]=\frac{1}{10}\left[\begin{matrix}30\\ 10\\ 20\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix} 3\\ 1\\ 2\end{matrix}\right]\] Then \(x_1=3,\ x_2=1,\ x_3=2\).

 

This approach, and another known as Cramer's rule (which is not covered here) are both rather tedious! The advantage of the inverse matrix method is that we can determine when there is a unique solution and we can operate on matrix equations abstractly, i.e. if we have \(AX+B=C\) and we know that \(A\) has an inverse then we can rewrite \(X=A^{-1}(C-B)\). By this we can simplify a problem algebraically before attempting any calculations. 

There are cases where the matrix is more simple than a general \(3 \times 3\) matrix due to the presence of zeros. In these cases the calculation will take less time and become more feasible.

We will soon see Gaussian elimination which is superior method for general matrices.
